2023-05-17 18:58 UTC: Changed notes to We at Bellingham Food Bank envision a community with a thriving food system where everyone has equitable access to the food they need and want.
We reduce hunger by:

--creating access to high quality, desirable food and other essentials.
--building a responsive regional hunger relief network.
disrupting racism, because of its historical and structural connection to hunger and poverty.

2023-05-17 18:58 UTC: Changed options to ""
2023-05-17 20:11 UTC: Changed notes to 
We reduce hunger by:

creating access to high quality, desirable food and other essentials.
building a responsive regional hunger relief network.
disrupting racism, because of its historical and structural connection to hunger and poverty.
VALUES OF THE BELLINGHAM FOOD BANK
Quality & Choice

We offer a variety of high-quality foods, culturally relevant foods, and other essentials. We strive to create a welcoming, respectful, and dignified experience.

Justice & Equity

We believe hunger, poverty, and systemic racism are inextricably linked. Food justice is social justice.

Inclusion & Access

We actively work to remove barriers to food and essentials and to offer what is familiar and valued by our diverse community.

Responsiveness & Innovation

We are adaptive and curious. We listen, experiment, learn, and adjust as we seek ways to deepen our impact on both immediate needs and the root causes of hunger.

Adopted November 2021

2024-09-04 16:39 UTC: Changed notes to We are a non-profit, charitable organization that distributes food to those who are going threw a difficult time. The food banks actively serve 100-150 families per week  (about 550-650 individuals).

Food donations can be made at the foodbank during open hours: 

Monday 11:30 - 3:00 pm
Tuesday 8:30 - 12:00 pm
Wednesday 8:30 - 12:00 pm
If you have a food drive donation or need to drop off at another time please give us a call at 360-825-8961. Special delivery arrangements can be made for food drives. 

Fresh produce can be delivered at any of the times above.

Canned goods and pre-packaged goods must be unopened and with current expiration dates. Other donations, such as toiletries, diapers, baby wipes and feminine products, are also welcomed! Travel-sized toiletries are also needed.

2023-07-10 19:56 UTC: Changed notes to What started out in 1984 as a humble effort to house families experiencing homelessness in two farmhouses and five rented apartments, has since grown into one of Orange County’s most impactful nonprofits. Tackling the pervasive issue of homelessness for families with children, last year Families Forward improved the lives of more than 13,000 people. From providing food assistance, career coaching, mental health counseling, to financial literacy education, we’re as committed to strengthening overall wellbeing as we are to ensuring everyone has a place to call home.

Our food pantry is open to families and individuals throughout all of Orange County. Families are able to access the food pantry Monday-Thursday between the hours of 10am-4pm and are able to come once a week.

2024-07-09 20:44 UTC: Changed notes to Founded in 1972, Second Harvest Food Bank Santa Cruz County was the first food bank in California and is the second oldest in the nation. In Santa Cruz County, 1 in 3 people face hunger. Hunger is not inevitable. We’re working hard to feed people who need food now and to advocate for policies that tackle the root causes of hunger. We reach people in need through our vast network of partner agencies and non-profits and directly through food distribution and nutrition education at dozens of program sites. Every month, 65,000 local residents count on us to avoid missing meals, empty stomachs, and impossible choices between food, housing, medicine, and other necessities.
2024-07-09 20:52 UTC: Changed notes to Founded in 1972, Second Harvest Food Bank Santa Cruz County was the first food bank in California and is the second oldest in the nation. In Santa Cruz County, 1 in 3 people face hunger. We reach people in need through our vast network of partner agencies and non-profits and directly through food distribution and nutrition education at dozens of program sites. Every month, 65,000 local residents count on us to avoid missing meals, empty stomachs, and impossible choices between food, housing, medicine, and other necessities. 1896 volunteers help power Second Harvest Food Bank Santa!
Cruz County.
